I have a lot of memories there. I have played basketball, football, and baseball there with the other guys in the neighborhood before. I also ended up with one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, whenever I go to that park it is to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger than me and still like playing on swings and slides and all of that type of stuff. Just the thought of going to the park makes them excited. The park makes me very nostalgic for a number of different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You will find all kinds of food nearby. In just a one mile radius, you would be able to find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays, a lot of people just use apps just as GrubHub and DoorDash to get their food delivered to them. The most popular food places are the fast food shops but you can get those near pretty much any suburban neighborhood. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here contain everything you would ever need. There are multiple dry cleaners nearby. There is a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street as well as a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is popular in the Midwest. Some of the stores are even diverse as there is an Indian-owned store if you are ever in the mood to make some homemade Indian food or to buy some ready-made Indian food. Overall, I am a fan of my neighborhood. Reading on social media and seeing on the news some of the horror stories other people have to go through with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.
My neighborhood is a quaint little town. It doesn't stand out from any other in South Carolina, but it's got a significant impact on the agriculture sector. Johnston is known as the Peach Capital of the World, something that the town proudly boasts about on the welcoming sign. It's primarily composed of farmland dominated by either peach trees or cattle. Houses that aren't located within the main part of town are widely spaced apart; most are two stories with either metal roofs to help combat the blazing summer heat or gray shingles. More often than not these houses aren't located near the road, but are further back allowing for the front fields to be used for animals/crops. Within the main part of town, there's a single stop light that hangs at a four way. Here is where the only stores in the entire town are located. There are three places in which you can get "fast food': Hong Kong, a small Chinese restaurant run by a single family, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's, a small burger chain. There used to be a pizzeria, however it closed down a short time ago. There is a very small family-owned pharmacy called Maxwell and Halford Drug; funnily enough, they're best known for the Cherry Coca-Cola they sell. There is a small, but expensive grocery store called Independent Grocers Alliance, more commonly known as IGA. While it is the only grocery store in the entire town, many individuals only stop to pick up one or two items; most prefer to travel to a Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville in order to purchase the majority of their groceries. The most popular store in the entire town is Dollar General; this store sells a vast array of everyday items and it often busy from the moment it opens until closing time! There is a very small furniture store, Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a kind woman who is well-known within the community. The store has been in Johnston for a plethora of years and even employs two movers who will deliver the purchased furniture! Attached to the furniture store building is a small pet groomers called Clark's Cuts and Kennels. They provide a multitude of services such as daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, bathing, etc. Both a doctor's and veterinary practice are situated away from the primary part of town; they are both very small practices, though well-equipped to aid the residents of Johnston. There is a single elementary school called Johnston Elementary School. Once students have completed fifth grade, they must attend both middle and high school in the next town over. There are technically no parks within the town, however they are currently in the midst of creating a 2.5 acre recreational area in order to provide families with more opportunities to enjoy outings and attract more visitors/potential residents. Admittedly there isn't much to do; there are no movie theaters, bowling alleys, "hang out" spots, playgrounds for children, areas to walk pets, or a large variety of restaurants. Despite this it's a nice town, so small that you could pass in the blink of an eye without realizing!
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
transformed_texts: My city is a melting pot of diversity. Neighborhoods are scattered between commercial areas, where all sorts of businesses thrive. Offices, stores, and restaurants galore, some big-name brands, some small boutiques. They're everywhere, even in quiet neighborhoods, making them no longer so serene. Parks abound, and people love bringing their children there. The folks here are diverse too. In one area, there's a strong LGBTQ+, Orthodox Jewish, and Soviet refugee community. Step outside, and you'll find more races and origins. Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, they're just miles away, but those miles can be long and congested. Traffic's a nightmare, and parking? Forget about it. Yet, new apartment buildings are popping up everywhere. It's a hot spot, but residents are grumpy about more people and cars. Houses come in all shapes and sizes, from single-family homes to condos. There's even a mix of ages in the neighborhood, but I barely know my neighbors. It's not a tight-knit community anymore, but I have fond memories of playing with my childhood friends.

My neighborhood is quite unique. Most houses are single-family homes, but you'll find a few that have been divided into two, while still being attached to each other, if you catch my drift. My house boasts a small yard in front and a driveway to the left. It, like many others, is a reminder of a time when living in the suburbs was the American dream. While that dream seems to be waning, our neighborhood and many others like it still stand, still clinging to it as best we can. The people here aren't as optimistic as they used to be, the yards aren't as well-maintained, but there's still a car or two in every driveway, and the kids play as if the world revolves around them. The local school, standing tall for nearly 90 years, continues to inspire today's youth while evoking nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are always filled with kids. The homes may look different, but they all feel the same. There's a large supermarket called Super "A", owned by a Yemeni family, possibly the only Arab family in the neighborhood. Most residents are African American. The streets are wide, and the kids play football, pausing only to let cars pass. Many residents have lived here for generations, and they've got stories to tell about a time when everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school once, but when Hollywood stopped making karate movies, the kids lost interest, so it became a pharmacy. “Drugs make everything better,” I’ve heard. There's also an old movie theater that shows classic films at a discount, shunned by the youth but loved by the elders, who see it as a small price to pay for a night out without the kids. There’s an expressway that passes through our town, with the exits and entrances in the neighboring town. There was a petition to build an exit for our town, but the youth supported it while the elders refused. They were concerned that having an expressway would ruin the town, and they convinced the city council to deny the request. A new high school is being built, and we're trying to decide on a mascot. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be the perfect representation of our town.

You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it's a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you walk behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and the hotels that are only used annually for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. These communities are lined with apartment complexes, situated side by side like Russian nesting dolls that have been carefully taken apart and set down the road, piece by piece. The first apartment complex you come across has been on the news for some unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on that too much - appearances can be deceiving. But the complexes next to it and the ones beside that one are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from these complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to start their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to let them in one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days with high attendance. The road intersects with another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people with broken bones on the other. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture and a lazily spinning ceiling fan that churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There's a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park with inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside it, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There's a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.

“Where are we?” she asked as we drove by the endless cornfields stretching out in every direction. “This is it!” I replied, knowing she’d be surprised by the expansive open landscape. She was from a town where the grocery store was just a 5-minute walk from her door, and she’d never seen such vast emptiness. Stunned by the omnipresence of cornfields, I told her about growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally understood who I was and where I came from.

Driving along the two-lane country road, you’ll reach a quarry filled with water. Just past it lies the small housing development where I live. The homes are mostly brick and stucco, each with at least half an acre of land taken pride in by their owners. During spring, vibrantly colored flowers and midwestern trees abound, changing with each season. Luxury Mercedes Benz cars gleam in the midday sun after a good wash. The driveways are filled with these high-end vehicles.

Continuing toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly smile. He spends the whole day mowing his lawn, often singing over the hum of his mower. Everyone in the neighborhood finds him amusing, but he’s genuine and has a fascinating past. He was a doctor once, now blending into the grass and his John Deere Zero Turn mower. Eventually, you’ll reach my house. The side yard is filled with geese that our Terrier chases. Out back lies a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Crossing the wooden bridge is an untouched oasis with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This was where I spent most of my childhood, building tree forts and hunting “animals” (really just chasing them). There’s always something to do and a neighborhood child to play with.

Winters in our small town can be harsh, but there’s nothing more beautiful. The yard turns into an empty wilderness, with trees shedding their vibrant colors, and a rare snowfall transforming it into a winter wonderland. Snow angels and snowmen line the backyard. My sister and I used to fight, and during winter, we’d use snowballs as our weapons. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to store our arsenal. It was our little wonderland, where we played without a care in the world.

The first thing you need to get is that Portland, Oregon is a place like no other. It's got a tagline, "Keep Portland Weird", plastered on the wall of a building that's a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on half those operations. It's a throwback to the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a place that was unknown and cheap, breeding all sorts of unique subcultures. To some, it's a call to come and be weird, not in a bad way, but in a way that's accepted, even celebrated. Despite the influx of transplanted Californians and the constant condo construction, Portland remains weird. Weird isn't about accepting everything, but it is about accepting things that are unusual. We have modern conveniences and modern issues, like everyone else, sourcing most of our goods from China. Every neighborhood has its own flavor of weird, but it's not all quirkiness. We've got yoga and hipsters and business professionals too. Maybe weird means we take all that less seriously. In my neighborhood, colorful houses, flower and herb gardens, and free boxes are common. Free boxes are magical, containing clothes, books, or anything someone doesn't want anymore. That's the Portland magic. That's what Portland is about to me, but I'm just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people in my neighborhood would never pick clothes from a sidewalk box. They'd rather go to goat yoga or a Timbers match (Portland's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people chasing dreams or dreaming about chasing dreams, spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem, often tied to mental health issues, and the constant rain and cloudy weather might exacerbate that. There's also a significant homelessness problem, drawn by Portland's social services, but not enough to help everyone. The non-homeless are divided between care and disdain. In this, Portland is just like any other city.

The mountains stand tall and unyielding, a constant presence in my life. From my northward view, they witness the sun's daily ascent and descent, unperturbed by the passage of time or the turmoil of life. Even when I am consumed by work and daily life, taking notice of them seems to elude me. Yet, on days of great stress and anxiety, they call out to me, offering solace and strength to carry on, one day at a time. It was during my undergraduate years that I first moved here, and the mountains to the north of campus were the first to steal my heart. While the university and town both have their own unique charms, it is the mountains that reign supreme in my affection.

The city is a blend of the old and the new. Just a short walk or bus ride away from the college campus lies a bustling downtown area, characterized by its vintage brick buildings. This urban vibe is interrupted by the quiet, picturesque neighborhoods nestled around the library, providing a stark contrast to the city's energy. This dynamic mix of atmospheres creates an inviting atmosphere, begging to be explored and cherished. The town holds a special place in my memory, with each locale tied to a particular joy or sorrow.

One of my fond memories includes late-night walks through the park, past the rusted swings, often with friends after an intense study session. On other occasions, I would dash through the busy downtown to catch a movie in the upscale theater, an indulgence provided by the university. However, this town is not without its hardships. The ponds, in particular, have seen their share of tears and introspection, especially during those late-night existential crises. Watching the turtles, ducks, and insects live out their lives has often led me to question my own purpose. It was during these moments that I found my way to the main street, where the sun would cast its golden rays upon the palm trees, painting the sky. As I gazed up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking towards my old friends, the mountains. They stood tall and steadfast, their peaks touching the hazy blue and yellow sky, and as if sharing a secret, they reminded me of my inner strength.

If you're planning a visit to Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, finding the place won't be a problem! Public transport is abundant and widely used in New York City. Bensonhurst is a bustling urban neighborhood, so you'll still be in the heart of the city. Be prepared to spot plenty of Asian stores as you walk around. The neighborhood has seen a significant influx of Asian residents over the past two decades, leading to Asian-owned businesses, particularly supermarkets and laundromats, every block. These businesses are beloved by locals for their excellent food, affordable prices, and convenience. Just near me, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walk of each other, enhancing the accessibility of grocery shopping. Bensonhurst isn't exclusively Asian, though. It's quite diverse with immigrants and their children from first and second generations. Many large businesses in the area are Asian-owned, but there's also a recently renovated park nearby, featuring around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground, and a child-friendly water fountain. NYC parks are diverse, and you'll see a mix of people getting along well. There aren’t many corporate buildings here; most are co-op or condo apartments, with two-family houses predominant. Most residents are friendly, but the neighborhood can be noisy, especially from cars blasting music or accelerating through the streets. At night, keep your guard up as the neighborhood is generally safe but can be unpredictable with people starting trouble, bullies, and thieves. I've been bullied in the past through physical assault, and package theft occurs too. Morning commutes can be unpleasant due to dog waste on sidewalks. Keep your shoes clean!

The sidewalks are scarce around here, and my house sits atop the steepest hill in the neighborhood, earning it the nickname "workout hill" for the joggers who love to run uphill daily. The streets are pot-holed and somewhat treacherous, and a lot of telephone and electric wires look worn out from the frequent rainfall and storms. The constant repairs make them look like a patchwork quilt. Tall evergreen trees abound, but the locals don't much appreciate them; they block the ocean view and obstruct the view of the bay. As a result, many houses are built high up on the hill with large glass-fronted second stories. At sunset, the water glows and the sky turns orange, but it's often cloudy, and the view is usually obscured by a haze. Moss grows on everything it can, including cars and railings. I once left my car parked for a month and it was covered in moss when I returned. It took me three hours to scrape it off. There aren't many children around, but there's a school nearby, and the neighborhood is populated mostly by older folks and retirees. Instead of kids, the locals have dogs; they're often seen in people's lawns or racing down the street. Occasionally, a dog might sneak into someone's house if a door or window is left open. Rabbits are a common sight, and gardeners dislike them because they damage plants and dig up lawns. My cats have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. Birds are also abundant, ranging from small sparrows and hummingbirds to the occasional hawk or eagle, which gets chased off by the neighborhood crows. There aren't many stores nearby, but if you walk downhill to the waterfront, you'll find a few restaurants serving fresh seafood. The beach isn't very wide, but the rocks along the shore are fun to toss into the water. The bay isn't very wide, and you can see the other shore through the mist on most days.

I reside in a typical suburban area of a small southern town in Tennessee. Our street connects two state highways, so we experience a bit more traffic than I'd prefer, but overall, it's a quiet neighborhood. The folks around here are rather permanent, and I've grown familiar with most of them. They keep themselves busy with yard work and daily chores. In the winter, we make use of the hill on our side street for sledding. Our house is situated at the front corner of our street, so we observe everyone coming and going throughout the day and recognize the cars that drive around. Whenever we see an unfamiliar vehicle, we take note. Some neighbors engage in walking for exercise or to walk their dogs, while the kids enjoy riding their bikes. We spend a significant amount of time at home since we work from there. My wife and I have two daughters, aged eleven and fourteen, so we're a familiar sight to the neighbors. We enjoy going outside to play, sometimes even in the rain. Occasionally, we'll grill on our back deck, and the smell from the barbecue is always pleasant. Lawn mowers are a common sound from March to October as the grass grows, and we enjoy the smell of burning leaves in the Fall, which indicates the arrival of the season. Recently, we've had a long Fall as the winter has been minimal. Our garage is at the rear of the house, so we use the front door mainly when someone knocks, which doesn't happen often. I like to work on my truck or other projects in the garage, and when the garage doors are open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. During holidays, the neighborhood is quiet. Thanksgiving and other similar events bring in extra cars as families from out of town visit. Overall, I enjoy living here, and if it weren't a through street, it would be ideal.

My neighborhood is smack dab in the middle of the high desert, where the only color you see is brown. Unless you've been here, you won't understand how it feels to see dirt everywhere, and when you do see a green lawn, you know that person's spending a mint on lawn care. Back in the 90s, houses were scattered all over the place, but now it's mostly the same, with a bunch of new additions. It's starting to look like a city, but I guess that's how most places are changing these days. The people are generally friendly, but it's like any city - you've got your good parts and bad. I live among a bunch of friendly old folks, so I'd say it's a nice neighborhood.

The stores here are mostly chains like Food4Less and Smart & Final. If you want upscale shopping, you'll have to travel. I've never seen a Whole Foods or anything like that around here. The most common jobs are construction - it's because this city's still not fully developed, so there's plenty of open space to build on. That kind of scares me, I like things the way they are now. I left a big city and I'm not looking to go back. Speaking of construction, that's where my full-time job is - I'm a drywall and T-bar installer.

What I love about my home is the wildlife. People come to the high desert for its stark beauty, and the unique ecosystems created by the climate and topography. We have a bunch of different animals here, and my kids are obsessed with them. Right now, they're outside trying to catch lizards and desert bugs.

As for attractions, Victorville's a great place for families to experience the desert. If you can, try to visit during the San Bernardino County Fair. It's the perfect mix of activities and fun. Plus, you can pop over to Wrightwood and enjoy the snow-covered mountains. If you're interested in natural history and culture, check out the Victor Valley Museum. It's got geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of Victorville's development.

When it comes to what I consider my neighborhood, I'm sure my answer is a bit unconventional. Unlike others who might talk about their own home and community, I look at my neighborhood as the college campus I reside on, with the people living in my dormitory as my community. While the surrounding campus is also part of my neighborhood, albeit to a lesser extent, it has several similarities with more traditional neighborhoods. Let's start by discussing the "houses" that make up my neighborhood. Before diving into the specifics, it's important to clarify the types of housing I encounter. There are three primary types: apartments, actual houses, and dormitories.

In the apartments, you'll typically find between 2 to 4 people per room, with about 4 to 6 rooms per floor. A building that houses about 2 floors can accommodate around 20 people. The next type is the actual houses available for rent to those affiliated with the school. These are usually 2 to 4-bedroom setups, often occupied by alumni. Though less common, they are scattered throughout the neighborhood. Lastly, the dormitory-style housing, which houses hundreds of students, is the most prevalent type. In these, two people share a room as the norm, with some exceptions.

Now, let's talk about the people who make up this neighborhood. My school prides itself on diversity, and that's reflected in the residents of my neighborhood. You'll find people from various cultures and age groups. Professional staff tend to live in the houses, younger students in the dormitories, and older students in the apartment-style housing.

Moving on to the stores and parks, my neighborhood has a variety of dining options, the school's unique brand of clothing and grocery stores, and even a playground for the diverse community. Anything you might need is within walking distance. The park is kept clean and safe by the community, much like any other neighborhood.

Well, let me tell you, I've been hanging around here for about a decade now, so I guess I can spill the beans on what I've learned. First off, I was pretty bummed when I first rolled into Stockbridge. I came from Riverdale, and I'll be honest, I missed it something fierce. But my parents wanted the best for me and my sister, so we moved to a neighborhood that was supposedly "not ghetto" and had a better high school. It took some time to adjust, but I eventually made some new friends and even a few enemies at school. I never got to know my neighbors much, except for Mr. Glen and his crew next door, and Dennis for a bit. They've been great, and I mean that. I even caught Ms. Veda's bouquet at Mr. Glen's wedding! I miss those times. I wish I could share more about the neighborhood, but it's like a maze, and now I've got a GPS so I can take my time exploring it. I've only made it as far as hanging out with Kason and Curtis, and we'd play video games and live life to the fullest. There's also a park where I go to relax and enjoy nature, which helps me unwind. Sometimes I'll bring my bokken sword and practice my balance. I've got a basketball and tennis court too, even though I haven't played in years. My dad and Mr. Graves used to drill us in tennis, and we always had a blast. There's a lot of good times I've had here, and I'm looking forward to many more.

My living situation in the neighborhood is quite convenient since it's close to the college I attend. I live in an apartment building that's surrounded by a few restaurants and bars. One of the bars recently got a new name, and it's a bit pricier than the others, but the quality of service and drinks isn't bad. The people here are mostly either college students or lower-income individuals, which makes the atmosphere relaxed. There's an elementary school nearby, and while I don't know my neighbors, I don't mind since they tend to smoke a lot of weed. The management has put an air freshener unit outside their apartment, which my boyfriend and I find amusing, though it might be seen as rude. The buildings around me are mostly old, but some have been renovated. Down the street, there are newer apartment buildings, but they seem cheaply constructed and overpriced, likely due to their proximity to campus. There's a budget-friendly restaurant about five minutes away, serving food on paper plates, and most of it is microwaved. Across from it is a gas station known for its poor working conditions. However, the road was recently redone with city funds, making the area nicer. My apartment building is surrounded by trees, and while some were cut down, there are still quite a few. Behind my apartment complex is another row of trees, followed by more apartments. I live on 42nd Street, with 43rd Street right behind it, which is not as pleasant due to its dilapidated sidewalks and shabby buildings. There are a lot of trees on 43rd Street, likely to hide the buildings' condition. Crime is present in the area, particularly at the apartment complex on that street, but I can't point the finger at just them. There are also apartments across from me with similar issues. Despite this, I like my living situation as it's affordable and offers easy access to amenities, including the university and two bus stops for easy travel.

My neighborhood is a collection of duplexes arranged on a cul-de-sac, spaced out here and there to give the impression of individual homes. Most of the time, they're painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs. Nearly everyone in the neighborhood is friends with each other. In the evenings, we often gather at the end of the not-so-planned driveway, chatting while the neighborhood kids play with their toys, sidewalk chalk, or fly their kites. It's a refreshing change from our modern, tech-filled world, like stepping back in time. Surrounding us are fields and trees, enhanced by blue skies and white clouds. The big downside? We've been under tornado warnings this season, and last night, we even heard the sirens. So, I found myself in my bathtub with my little dog, purse, and pillows, while my big dog stayed in the living room, barking nervously. The neighborhood was quiet, except for the sound of hail pounding the ground. After the storm, the road was steaming from the temperature change, going from 92 degrees to 75 in minutes. The hail melted instantly on the hot pavement. As I looked up, the sun emerged and it started to rain, followed by a double rainbow. I grabbed my camera to share the sight with friends and family, who were just as amazed as I was. The streets remained quiet for another hour before folks started coming home. Then it was back to normal, with mothers and children outside as dinner cooked. It's a great neighborhood for this gal from New Hampshire who recently moved to North Carolina. I love the southern accents here. My place is a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment, like everyone else's. On the outside, all the houses look the same, but the apartments inside vary in size. Some are quite small, which doesn't make sense to me. I enjoy walking through the big field behind my place and strolling down to the pond, not meant for swimming. I've spotted deer and heard the giant bullfrog's morning song. It's a fantastic place to live, just forty minutes from Charlotte. Each morning is welcomed by rooster crows from nearby farms, making it feel like a small village community. There's even a donkey at a nearby farm that lets us know he's there with his evening bray. I was fortunate to find this gem of a neighborhood.

I moved into this neighborhood just as I was about to start eighth grade. Making friends was tough at first, but I ended up bonding with a guy living two houses down and another one on my street. They aren't here anymore, but the memories stay. The people who were here when I first moved are still around. My neighborhood is pretty standard for an American suburb; it's got lots of two-story houses. Weekends or whenever it's warm outside, you hear kids playing. Most days are quiet, and I've never had any problems with neighbors. They leave you alone unless you need help. I've ordered plenty of packages online and never had one snatched off my porch. I trust my neighbors. There's a park a couple minutes away where I've played basketball, football, and baseball with my neighbors. I have some bad memories there too, like getting elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good ones outweigh the bad. Now, I go to the park to spend time with my cousin's kids. They're younger and love playing on swings and slides. Visiting the park makes me nostalgic. The neighborhood is diverse. There are Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants within a one-mile radius. People these days mostly use apps like GrubHub and DoorDash for delivery. Fast food places are common, and there are plenty of pizza joints. Stores have everything you need. There are several dry cleaners, Walgreens, CVS, and a Jewel-Osco grocery store. There's even an Indian-owned store if you're into homemade or ready-made Indian food. Overall, I'm happy with my neighborhood. Seeing horror stories about other people's neighborhoods on social media makes me appreciate mine even more.

My neighborhood is a quaint little town in South Carolina. It doesn't jump out from the crowd, but it's got a significant impact in the agriculture sector. Johnston, as it's known, proudly boasts its status as the Peach Capital of the World on the welcoming sign. The town is mostly made up of farmland where peach trees and cattle are the dominant sights. Houses are scattered and typically have metal roofs to withstand the blazing summer heat or gray shingles. Most of these houses are a distance from the main road, allowing the front fields to be used for animals or crops. In the main town area, there's a single four-way stop with a stoplight. This is where you'll find the only stores in town. There are a few places to get "fast food": Hong Kong, a small Chinese restaurant run by a single family; Fiesta Mexican Restaurant; Gary's, a small burger chain; and a now-closed pizzeria. There's also Maxwell and Halford Drug, a small family-owned pharmacy best known for their Cherry Coca-Cola. The Independent Grocers Alliance, a small grocery store, is called IGA. While it's the only grocery store in town, many people prefer to travel to a Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville for most of their groceries. The most popular store is Dollar General, which offers a wide range of everyday items and is always busy. There's also a small furniture store, Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a kind woman who is well-known within the community. Attached is Clark's Cuts and Kennels, a pet groomers offering services like daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, and bathing. Both a doctor's and veterinary practice are located away from the main town area; they are small but well-equipped. The town only has a single elementary school called Johnston Elementary School, and students must attend middle and high school in the next town over. There are no parks, but they're working on creating a 2.5-acre recreational area to provide more opportunities for families and attract visitors. There's not much to do in town; no movie theaters, bowling alleys, hangout spots, playgrounds, or many restaurants. Despite this, it's a nice town, so small that you could pass through without realizing it!

The first time I heard about my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who've gone missing. It caught me off guard. Almost every apartment in the area was renting for over a thousand dollars a month. I couldn't believe it—neither had any of my friends. It's a struggle, that's for sure. I know some of my friends cry themselves to sleep thinking about it. It's expensive, but we've learned to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market finds and well-loved clothes. It's like the smell of adulthood, one that sticks even after you wash it. Here, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. If you start from the far side, you can shop at two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is bustling, with cars and people filling the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it inside the thrift stores. No matter how busy it is outside, the stores are always quiet. It's a great place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there seem to be more and more people and cars flooding the city. It's a developing place, they say. With one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery headquartered here, it's showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everyone is focused on their own goals and nobody asks too much of you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where showing too much concern means you care. Here, people don't pry into each other's lives. You can maintain your privacy as long as you like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. With the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors, and they treat me pretty well. I try to be considerate and leave them food, and they do the same. I bring mail for them, and they do for me. It's nice to see them, and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, impersonal modernist sprawl, but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I haven't totally ruined my life.

The place I call home is what you might expect from a typical cookie cutter suburb. A homeowner's association rules the roost here, and it shows in the pristine condition of everything. Front yards are uniform with a small patch of grass, a bit of decorative pebbles, and a short driveway. Some houses even have small trees. Everyone's got a two-car garage, and the streets are all freshly paved with no potholes in sight. The houses are mostly single story, though every now and then you'll see a two-story one. We don't have individual mailboxes like you'd find at some places. Instead, there's a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street, with two larger lockers for packages. The HOA's obsession with uniformity is evident here. My neighborhood is right at the edge of a nearby city, which makes it a mix of rural and suburban living. We've got plenty of land for everything. Multiple community pools are well-maintained and gated, and there are walking trails for dog walks or evening strolls. You don't need to visit a park to get your exercise. The neighborhood is big enough to run around for some good exercise. Most people here are retired, but there are some middle-aged and young professionals mixed in too. The city itself is large by population but has a small-town feel. All the amenities you'd expect are here, like a mall that's not huge but gets the job done. It's just a 15-minute drive to get to more significant places, and once there, you've got high-end grocery stores and bargain outlets. All in all, it's a safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical neighborhood. We've got nice things like pools and walking trails, and while we're not next door to any major shopping, a short drive gets you to any major chain you need.

I live in a cozy Midwestern town nestled just outside a bustling metropolis. My neighborhood, situated on the east side, is the town's most economically challenged area. Still, it's not unpleasant, and my neighbors are generally warm and welcoming. While crime rates are slightly higher, overall, it's quite low. We've had a few incidents, including a shooting and a homicide nearby, but my family hasn't been directly affected, aside from some minor thefts from our porch. The opioid epidemic has taken a toll on the town, but there are plenty of resources to combat it, like addiction rehab centers and Narcan training sessions. Despite these challenges, our town has plenty of positives. My son's elementary school is fantastic, with a supportive staff and a positive atmosphere. The PTO organizes great events, and they provide free breakfast and lunch to all students, ensuring no child goes hungry. The City Council has made improvements, like repaving roads and refurbishing parks, but these mainly target the central and western parts of town, leaving the east side feeling neglected. Still, I enjoy living here. The people are friendly, the schools are top-notch, and our home may not be worth much, but it's comfortable. We've been here for over 16 years and can't imagine living anywhere else.

My neighborhood is rich in culture and history. It's situated on a hill, surrounded by buildings with a story to tell. I live in a 7-story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill is a cool little arcade bar that attracts all sorts of folks on warm summer nights. On weekends in June and July, you'll often see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's quite spacious for the part of town it's in. Concrete encircles the park, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the cold winter months, homeless people set up their tents in neat rows along the sidewalk and the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains heavily, making it tough to stay warm. By setting up their tents close together and in the city center, they can keep warm and are also near the family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city isn't the old buildings or the architecture that dots the rolling hills towards the ocean. It's the people who make my neighborhood their home. Hilltop was once infamous for gang violence, with federal officials and the DEA sweeping through to clean the streets. The stories live on, even three decades later. The people here work hard to keep their neighborhood clean. They care about what happens in their city and on their block. They warn that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around Hilltop at night. That warning echoes the past, tinged with social conditioning. Maybe it's because I'm dark enough to pass for not entirely "white," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, who feels the constant reminders of our nation's problems. It's a place where I feel alive walking the streets at night, meeting people who offer a jacket more often than to rob me. It's where laundromat owners stay open late so I can charge my phone on rainy nights. It's a place where I can sit, feeling invisible, on grey and dreary nights at the mercy of the concrete store fronts, only to have someone stop and hand me $5, telling me I'm beautiful and valuable.

I reside in Rural America, nestled in a small Michigan town. Here, you transition from farmland to quaint tourist spots, with no big city malls, Wal-marts, or Applebee's in sight. Everything is a drive away. Yet, I'm blessed to call one of the most scenic places in the world home, surrounded by magnificent bodies of water - Lake Michigan to the east and Lake Charlevoix to the west. Everywhere you go, there's a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood embodies small-town living. Houses are unique, not cookie-cutter; many have basements visible from the road, and a mix of older aluminum siding and vibrant colors. Most homes have yards with trampolines, playsets, gardens, and fences for pets. It's a Middle America feel, reflecting hardworking folks building a life here. Kids zoom up and down the streets, neighbors wave, and dogs are walked or biked nearby. Lawns are well-kept, with no leaf piles and neatly trimmed plants. It's not a showy neighborhood, but a peaceful, safe haven perfect for raising a family. Nearby, you'll find the county sheriff's department, health department, recycling center, and baseball/softball fields. Our small-town airport is close by, and you'll hear small planes taking off and landing. A short walk leads to an ice cream parlor, and if you're up for it, downtown is just a bike ride away. It's a truly wonderful place to live.
